caption: Palestinians who left the northern Gaza Strip made their way south on Friday near Khan Yunis as calls to evacuate persisted.
image_1.context: It was a show of unity that would have been This week, thousands of Jews from across the political and theological spectrum gathered outside the United Nations, many wrapped in blue and white Israeli flags, coming together both to grieve and to condemn the assault. New York’s Jewish community is the largest outside of Israel, and it is often polarized, particularly regarding Israel and its treatment of Palestinians. Since the brutal terror attacks on Israelis last Saturday, many New York Jews said they have put aside those differences. By JOHN LELAND Shaken and Grieving, Jewish New Yorkers Put Aside Differences VOL. CLXXIII . . . . No. 59,941 © 2023 The New York Times Company SATURDAY, OCTOBER 14, 2023
image_1.description: The image depicts a busy street scene in what appears to be a Middle Eastern or North African urban area. In the foreground, there is a black Hyundai SUV with several mattresses and other items stacked on its roof. Behind it, a white truck is heavily loaded with people and various belongings, including mattresses and blankets. The people on the truck appear to be evacuating, as they are sitting among their belongings. The street is lined with buildings and billboards, some of which have Arabic text. There are several vehicles on the road, including cars and trucks, and a few pedestrians can be seen walking along the sidewalk. The atmosphere suggests a sense of urgency and movement, possibly due to an evacuation or displacement event. The sky is clear, indicating a sunny day.

caption: A demonstration outside the United Nations on Tuesday.
image_2.context: Particularly for liberal congregations, the attacks have prompted a reconsideration of the language “Right now people are hurting, and we just want to hold each other’s hand and let the divisions be in the back,” he said. “Our political position now makes no difference. Left, right, pro-occupation, antioccupation, don’t know about it — we’re hurting and we’re shocked and we’re horrified and we want Israel to get through this.” Amichai Lau-Lavie, an Israeliborn rabbi who has been vocal about both his criticisms and his love for Israel, said it was time to put aside divisions and focus on shared grief.  Mr. Goldstein said. When Israel comes under attack, Jewish New Yorkers — including those who might rarely think about Israel — feel the threat. One measure of this relationship: Gov. Kathy Hochul, Mayor Eric Adams and Attorney General Letitia James all addressed the crowd outside the United Nations, supporting both Israel and the city’s Jewish community. Yet that relationship has had its divisions, with many progressive congregations and secular Jews strongly criticizing Israel. This polarization has increased since the rise of the far-right government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and a judicial reform program aimed at weakening Israel’s court system.
image_2.description: The image depicts a large crowd gathered outside the United Nations building, participating in a demonstration. The scene is bustling with activity, as numerous people are seen holding and waving Israeli flags. The flags are predominantly white with blue stripes and a blue Star of David in the center. The crowd appears diverse, with individuals of various ages and backgrounds standing closely together. Some participants are wearing hats, while others have their heads uncovered. The atmosphere conveys a sense of unity and solidarity, as the demonstrators seem to be expressing support for Israel. The background shows the exterior of the United Nations building, characterized by its modern architectural style. The overall mood of the image is one of collective emotion and shared purpose, reflecting the sentiment of the context provided.

image_3.context: But rather than finding safety from a feared ground invasion, at least 70 people were killed along the way when Israeli airstrikes hit some of the vehicles fleeing south,the Gazan authorities said. Some Gaza residents said they feared this could be the JERUSALEM — Panic and chaos gripped the northern Gaza Strip Friday as thousands of people fled south in vehicles piled high with blankets and mattresses along two main roads after the Israeli military ordered a mass evacuation of half of the besieged coastal strip. By RAJA ABDULRAHIM Gaza Residents Flee Amid Fears Of Never Being Able to Return Gaza within 24 hours. “We understand it will take time,” Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari, the chief military spokesman, told reporters. In Gaza, already cut off from vital supplies, many people fled with what they could carry, not knowing what conditions awaited them in the south or how long they would be gone. But many others remained, out of necessity, fear or defiance. Hamas, the militant group that controls Gaza and conducted a deadly, large-scale incursion into Israel last weekend, has urged people to stay put, calling the Israeli directive “psychological warfare.” On both sides, there is wideContinued on Page A8
image_3.description: The image is a map highlighting the area of evacuation in Gaza City. The map shows the geographical layout of the region, with the Mediterranean Sea to the west and Israel to the east. The area of evacuation is outlined in red and encompasses a significant portion of Gaza City. Key locations are marked, including Erez Crossing to the northeast, Sharia Al-Rashid and Salah Al-Din streets within the city, and Wadi Gaza to the south. The scale indicates that the map covers approximately 5 miles. The map is sourced from The New York Times.

caption: Louise Glück in late 2020.
image_4.context: The completion of Microsoft’s Activision acquisition is The deal, the largest consumer tech acquisition since AOL bought Time Warner more than two decades ago, won approval from British regulators on Friday, the last remaining regulatory obstacle. SAN FRANCISCO — Microsoft said on Friday that it had closed its \$69 billion purchase of the video game giant Activision Blizzard, overcoming significant regulatory hurdles in Britain and the United States and signaling that the tech industry’s giants are still free to use their cash hoards to get even bigger. By KELLEN BROWNING and DAVID McCABE Microsoft Gets Merger at Last With Activision the Nobel. She began publishing in the 1960s and received some acclaim in the ’70s, but she cemented her reputation in the ’80s and early ’90s with a string of books, including “Triumph of Achilles” (1985), which won the National Book Critics Circle Award; “Ararat” (1990); and “The Wild Iris” (1992), which won the Pulitzer Prize.  Her work was both deeply personal — “Ararat,” for example, drew on the pain she experienced over the death of her father — and broadly accessible, both to critics, who praised her clarity and precise lyricism, and to the broader Continued on Page A24
image_4.description: The image is a portrait of Louise Glück, taken in late 2020. She has shoulder-length, wavy gray hair and is wearing a black top with a fur collar. The background appears to be an outdoor setting with blurred trees and foliage, suggesting a natural environment. The lighting is soft, casting a gentle glow on her face and highlighting the texture of her hair and the fur collar. The overall mood of the image is serene and contemplative, capturing a moment of quiet reflection.

They appear to be shepherds or farmers, guiding the sheep across what looks like a bridge or a wide road. The background shows a cloudy sky with some trees and a distant building, possibly indicating an urban setting. The sheep are densely packed, filling the entire frame of the image. The atmosphere is one of organized chaos, as the men navigate through the sea of sheep. The colors in the image are muted, with the white and gray of the sheep contrasting against the darker clothing of the men and the light blue of the sky.

image_7.description: The image depicts three cyclists riding on a dirt or gravel road in an autumnal forest setting. The cyclists are dressed in cycling gear, with helmets and specialized jerseys. The cyclist on the left is wearing a light pink jersey, the middle cyclist is in a dark blue jersey, and the cyclist on the right is in a red and black patterned jersey. They are all riding road bikes, which are characterized by their thin tires and drop handlebars. The background shows tall trees with leaves that have turned yellow and orange, indicating the fall season. The ground is covered with fallen leaves, adding to the autumnal atmosphere. The cyclists appear to be in motion, suggesting they are actively cycling through the forest. The scene conveys a sense of adventure and enjoyment of nature, as the cyclists navigate through the scenic landscape.
